note.p: Kinloch Falconer was active in Democratic politics in Mississippi during Reconstruction and served as Mississippi’s secretary of state in 1878.

Born on October 28, 1838, Falconer grew up in Holly Springs, Mississippi. As a young man he worked at the Southern Herald (his father’s newspaper) and attended the University of Mississippi, graduating in 1860 on the eve of the Civil War. When the war broke out, Falconer enlisted in the 9th Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Recognized for his intelligence and writing ability, Falconer was soon promoted and moved to administrative and staff work, first serving as the private secretary and then adjutant general for Confederate General Braxton Bragg. Later he served as a staff officer for Confederate General Joseph E. Johnston during the Atlanta Campaign in the summer of 1864.

After the defeat of the Confederacy, Falconer returned to Mississippi and reentered the newspaper business, becoming editor of the Holly Springs Reporter. He began fostering an interest state politics and unsuccessfully ran for lieutenant governor as a Democrat under Benjamin G. Humphreys in 1868. In 1870, Falconer stepped away from editorial duties at the Reporter to practice law full time. He continued participating in Democratic politics and in 1877 was elected secretary of state. He entered that office in January 1878. However, only a few months later, a yellow fever epidemic struck parts of Mississippi. Falconer’s brother and father were stricken by the mosquito-borne disease. He went to Holly Springs to aid in their care, but both men died. Falconer himself then came down with the disease and died on September 23, 1878. He is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(The Daily Clarion, Meridian, MS, June 22, 1864; The Grenada Sentinel, Grenada, MS, May 16, 1868; The Clarion, Jackson, MS, February 3, 1870; The. Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, November 6, 1878; Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

James Davis Porter was an attorney, Confederate officer, and governor of Tennessee during the nineteenth century.

Born on December 7, 1828, in Paris, Tennessee, received two degrees from the University of Nashville in the 1840s and then studied law at Cumberland University. He became a practicing attorney in 1851 and later entered state politics. Elected to the Tennessee House of Representatives as a Whig in 1859, he introduced resolutions which advocated for his state to side with the lower south during the secession crisis following Abraham Lincoln’s election to president in 1860. When the Civil War broke out in April 1861, following the Confederate attack on federal soldiers at Fort Sumter in South Carolina, Porter’s resolutions were adopted by the Tennessee legislature and helped lead that state to declare its own secession from the Union.

Porter volunteered for Confederate military service and was commissioned as an officer, serving on the staffs of several Confederate generals during the Civil War. He participated in many notable battles of the western theater, including Shiloh, Chickamauga, and Atlanta.

After the war ended, Porter returned to Paris, Tennessee, and resumed practicing law. He returned to the political scene in 1870, joining the Democratic Party, and serving as a delegate to Tennessee constitutional convention. Afterwards, he accepted an appointment as a circuit court judge. In 1874, Porter ran for governor of Tennessee. He easily won against a Republican opponent and served two terms, leaving office in 1879. Porter focused much of his effort as governor to reduce the state’s debt, but he also promoted education, and supported anti-alcohol policies.

Upon leaving the governor’s office, Porter became involved in railroad business. Though successful, in 1885 he returned to public office, receiving appointment as Assistant Secretary of State under President Grover Cleveland, and then in 1893 accepting a diplomatic appointment as U.S. minister to Chile. Late in life Porter wrote a book about Tennessee during the Civil War and served as president of the Tennessee Historical Society.
Porter died on May 18, 1912. He was married to Susannah Dunlap. The couple had six children, although only three survived to adulthood. Porter is buried in Paris City Cemetery in Paris, Tennessee.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.
(Wikipedia)

John Marshall Stone served as governor of Mississippi two separate times, from 1876 to 1882 and from 1890 to 1896.

Born in Milan, Tennessee, on March 29, 1876, Stone grew up mostly in poverty but worked for his education and eventually became a school teacher. He moved to Mississippi in the mid-1850s and found work as a railroad station agent at Iuka, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Stone joined the Confederate army. He was placed in command of Company K of the 2nd Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Proving capable in battle during campaigns in Virginia, he was promoted in 1862 to colonel of the regiment and received high praise from his superiors during the rest of the war. Stone led his regiment until near the end of the war, when he was captured in North Carolina and sent to Ohio as a prisoner.

Upon his release after the Civil War, Stone returned to Mississippi and resumed his work with the Mississippi and Ohio Railroad at Iuka. He married Mary G. Coman in 1872 and had two children, both of whom died before adulthood. Stone and his wife also adopted and raised three of his nephews.

He entered politics in 1869, winning election to the Mississippi state senate as a Democrat. In 1873 and 1874, Democrats in Mississippi gained majority power following campaigns of voter intimidation and violence against African Americans and Republicans. Stone worked his way to president pro tempore of the Senate during this period. In 1876, the Democrat majority in the state legislature carried out an impeachment campaign against top Republican officials, including Governor Adelbert Ames and Lieutenant Governor Alexander K. Davis. When Davis was impeached and Ames was forced to resign to avoid a costly lawsuit against politically-driven impeachment charges, Stone became next in line for governor. He was sworn into office in March 1876.

Stone served as acting-governor for a year and a half and then won the gubernatorial election in 1877, running as the sole candidate. He lost reelection in 1881 to Robert Lowry, but retained his interest in the governor’s office and ran again—and won—in 1889. Mississippi adopted a new constitution in 1890, which in part extended Stone’s gubernatorial term until 1896 to aid the transition of new policies. The new constitution prohibited successive gubernatorial terms. Thus, Stone could not run for immediate reelection. Upon leaving office, he received an appointment as president of the Mississippi Agricultural and Mechanical College (now Mississippi State University) in Starkville. He died in 1900 and is buried at Oak Grove Cemetery in Iuka, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Dan Sansing, “John Marshall Stone: Thirty-first and Thirty-third Governor of Mississippi: 1876-1882; 1890–1896,” Mississippi History Now)

note.p: James Hill served in various Mississippi state offices after the Civil War, most notably as secretary of state from 1874 to 1878. He was the last African American to hold a state level office in Mississippi until the twentieth century.

Born on the plantation of James Hill in Marshall County, Mississippi, in 1837 or 1838, Hill was referred to as a mulatto in nineteenth century terminology, indicating he was likely biracial. Rumored to be the biological son of the plantation owner (whose name he shared), Hill was legally a slave under policies that established a child inherited the labor status of the mother. As he grew, Hill reportedly was taught how to read by the slave owner’s two white daughters, and he subsequently acquired machining skills at railroad shops in Holly Springs. He earned a reputation as a first-class mechanic.

Upon gaining his freedom after the Civil War, Hill’s previous education and technical skills made him a strong candidate for new opportunities for African Americans in Republican Reconstruction. He received an appointment as land registrar of Mississippi in 1867 and a year later was elected to the Mississippi state legislature. During his term as a legislator, he helped elect Hiram Revels to the U.S. Senate—the first African American to serve in that position.

In 1873, African American voters in Mississippi helped elect a series of candidates dedicated to racial equality, including northern-born Republican Adelbert Ames as Mississippi governor and Black attorney Alexander K. Davis as lieutenant governor. Hill was elected Mississippi’s secretary of state. Democrats in Mississippi almost immediately conducted a campaign of violence and intimidation against Republican and Black voters, sweeping several subsequent elections and stacking the Mississippi legislature with white supremacist representatives by 1875. The conservative Democrats in office tried clear state Republicans from top state positions, holding impeachment proceedings against Ames and Davis. Both men were removed from office in early 1876, but Hill retained his seat as secretary of state, and completed his term in 1878.

He remained in public service, serving as district internal revenue collector and then postmaster in Vicksburg, appointments given by the president. Following these assignments, Hill served as president of the Mississippi Cotton Manufacturing Company in Jackson. He received one more appointment, in the United States General Land Office in Jackson in 1900. Three years later, in February 1903, he started the Mississippi State Register, a weekly newspaper that advocated racial harmony. Unfortunately, he died of heart failure less than six months later. Hill never married or had children. He is buried in Mount Olive Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Christina Hudson, “James Hill (1837?-1903),” Black Past)

Located in Davidson County, Nashville was founded in 1780 under the name Nashborough in then Washington District of North Carolina and was renamed Nashville in 1784. On May 26, 1790 it became part of Southwest Territory until the creation of the state of Tennessee on June 1, 1796, when it became part of Davidson County. It was incorporated and became the county seat in 1806, and in 1843, Nashville became the state capital of Tennessee. (Wikipedia; Tennessee Encyclopedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Lafayette County, Oxford was founded in 1837 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia)
Located in Shelby County, Memphis was founded in 1819 and serves as the county seat. (Britannica; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: When the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it failed to abolish involuntary servitude. The amendment included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of African Americans, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies.

Immediately after the war, many states passed "Black Codes" or laws severely limiting African Americans' rights. Under these codes and other similar laws passed in the decades following the Civil War, African Americans could be arrested for any number of petty crimes, including vagrancy (functionally construed to mean any act of social mobility not approved by a white person) or theft (in Mississippi a felony if exceeding $10 worth of goods). Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality led to a dramatic expansion in the population of imprisoned individuals and an overwhelming number of African Americans within that population. Many states leased those convicted persons to private companies or individuals for their labor, and in certain cases lessees had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased.

Laborers worked in a variety of settings including shipbuilding and timber cutting, yet the most prominent form in states like Mississippi remained large-scale agricultural work. The convict lease system was incredibly dangerous and difficult for those who lived through it, as leased persons faced unsafe working conditions, inadequate living conditions, abuse from lessees, and grueling work schedules. Given these circumstances, the ready availability of imprisoned laborers, and the callousness of lessees and state officials, the mortality rate among convict laborers was incredibly high.

Certain states ceased leasing imprisoned persons to individuals or private companies in the late nineteenth century, only to continue using that labor on state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of African Americans while perpetuating anti-Black racism and laying the foundations of the modern prison-industrial complex (Library of Congress; Mississippi Encyclopedia).

While the Mississippi Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. Bills are originated in either house, and to become law, must receive a simple majority in both chambers. Once passed, it is sent to the Mississippi state governor for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and the state legislature can overcome the veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

While the U.S. Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. U.S. Congress divides legislators into separate committees who write federal or national legislation, and a vast industry of lobbyists also help members write legislation on behalf of corporate and labor interests. Once written, the proposed legislation is introduced to both houses, and if the bill passes both chambers by a majority vote, it is sent to the U.S. President for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and Congress can overcome the President's veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

Mississippi held a convention in early 1868 to draft a new constitution with Reconstruction reforms, a requirement for the state to regain political autonomy from military control. The convention saw fierce debates over the rights of African Americans and Republican policies, but by May 1868 had produced a draft constitution that outlawed slavery, extended voting rights and firearm ownership to African Americans, established public schools for all children in Mississippi, and protected property rights for married women. The draft constitution failed ratification by a public vote of 63,860 to 56,231 in June 1868. President Ulysses S. Grant announced that the constitution would be put to popular vote again in November but one article at a time. The voters in the November 1868 election ratified the constitution almost in its entirety—the only section to fail being that which restricted ex-Confederates from public service. The new constitution went into effect in January 1869 and led to Mississippi’s return to the union in early 1870. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

The United States Constitution was ratified in 1788 as the foundational code of laws for the United States of America. It was crafted in 1787 by a convention in Philadelphia originally tasked only with amending the existing Articles of Confederation, which had loosely combined the states under a weak central government. Delegates chose to set aside the articles entirely and create a stronger federal government made of three branches: the legislative (comprising two separate parts, the House of Representatives and the Senate), the judicial (led by the Supreme Court), and the executive (headed by the President of the United States). The Constitution sought to carefully balance competing interests regarding state and national authority, as well as large and small state representation. It also created a more direct relationship between Americans and the national government.

The convention’s departure from its original mandate to amend the Articles of Confederation generated controversy, particularly among Americans who opposed placing a distant central authority of the states. The Constitution’s supporters advocated the need for a stronger national government and explained that the federal system preserved state authority for most local matters. To guarantee enough support for ratification, the Constitution’s supporters agreed to add an addendum to more directly protect individuals' specific rights and freedoms. The Constitution was ratified in 1788 and the new United States government began in early 1789. Shortly afterwards, the new Congress adopted several amendments to the Constitution, ten of which were ratified by three-fourths of the states and became known as the Bill of Rights. These first ten amendments guaranteed certain rights for American citizens. Since then, seventeen additional amendments have been ratified to the United States Constitution. Three of them—the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Amendments—were adopted between 1865 and 1870, during the Reconstruction Era. The Thirteenth Amendment formally abolished slavery. The Fourteenth Amendment provides equal protection for all laws and the Fifteenth Amendment protects voting rights for American citizens regardless of “race, color, or previous condition of servitude,” both specifically to combat racial discrimination against African Americans following the end of slavery. (Wikipedia; National Archives and Records Administration)

A bar association is a professional association of attorneys, often responsible for regulating the legal practices and standards in their communities. The use of the word “bar” is tied to the traditional presence of a railing in court room to separate court proceeding from the public viewing area. In the United States, bar association requirements vary. Most are now organized as corporations. Many states require lawyers to be members of a respective bar association to practice law. Attorneys typically must pass bar exams to demonstrate proficiency in their state’s laws, regulations, and legal practices for admission to a bar association. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Attorney General Office of Mississippi is located in Jackson, Mississippi and was created in 1817 by the Constitution of Mississippi. The Attorney General was a legislatively-elected position with a one-year term until 1832 when the office become popularly-elective and the term was extended. (Wikipedia)

Opened in Nashville in 1831, the first Tennessee State Penitentiary initially instituted a program in which prisoners were put to work each day and separated into their own cells each, and prohibited from communicating with each other or outsiders. The prison began accepting female convicts in 1840. During the Civil War, the Union Army took control of the penitentiary and used it to house military prisoners. After the war, the racial makeup of prisoners at the penitentiary changed drastically. Before the Civil War, roughly 5% of prisoners were Black; by 1869 African Americans made up more than 60% of the penitentiary’s population.

Throughout the nineteenth century, Tennessee prison officials forced convicts to perform manual labor. The practice became a money-making program for state officials, especially when private companies contracted prison labor. In 1870, the Tennessee penitentiary established a convict-leasing program with the Tennessee Coal, Iron, and Railroad Company. Free laborers objected to the company’s use of cheap prison labor, leading to protests and strikes. The program continued, but these tensions helped contribute to growing labor organization in late nineteenth century America.
A new facility was built in the 1890s, although problems with overcrowding continued well into the twentieth century. (Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

ADELBERT AMES, ^J. M. Stone^ Governor of the State of Mississippi,

To the Sheriff of Lafayette County,
Or to the Sheriff of any other County--GREETING:

Whereas, His Excellency the Governor of the State of Ten-nessee—has made known to me that Eddie Cole, convicted of Larceny, at a regular stands charged with having committed the crime of Term of the Criminal Court of Shelby County, Tennessee, (as set forth in the annexed copy of an affidavit, Transcript of a Judgement which is hereby certified to be authentic,) in the on the 18th day of January, of 1875, and sentenced to on the [gap] day of [gap] 18[gap]; Five years imprisonment in the Penitentiary,
AND, WHEREAS, It appears that said [gap] has fled from justice has escaped from the Penitentiary of said State, and is to be found in the State of Mississippi, where he has taken refuge;

AND WHEREAS, the Governor aforesaid, has demanded of me the arrest and delivery of said Eddie Cole—to C. E. Butler—whom he has appointed agent to receive and convey said Eddie Cole,—to the jurisdictional limits within which he stands charged.

Now, Therefore, I, ADELBERT AMES, ^J. M. Stone^ Governor of the State of Mississippi, do, by virtue of the power vested in me by the Constitution and Laws of this State, direct and require you to arrest the said Eddie Cole—and deliver him to the custody of the said C. E. Butler, the agent appointed by the Governor of Tennessee,—to the end that he may be conveyed to the jurisdictional limits where he stands charged.
[seal] THE GREAT SEAL OF THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI [/seal]
IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, Witness my hand and signature, and the Great Seal of the State of Mississippi hereunto affixed, this 3d day of June, A. D., 1876.
J M Stone

James Hill
SECRETARY OF STATE.
[seal]

State of Tenn
Shelby County

Be it remembered that at a regular term of the Crimin-al Court of Shelby County, for the said County & State began and held at the Court House in the city of Memphis on the 18th day of Jan. 1875 the same being the 3rd Monday in Jan. 1875 present and presiding The Hon. Jno. R. Flippin Judge &etc the following is of record.

State of Tennessee
VS
Eddie Cole
Indictment for Larceny

Comes the attorney General on the part of the State and the defendant in proper person, who being arraigned at the bar of the Court and charged on the bill of Indictment. pleads not guilty to the same and for his trial puts himself upon the Country and the attorney General both the like, when to try the issue of traverse joined between the State of Ten-nessee and the Defendant—Eddie Cole—then came a jury of good and lawful men, who having been elected, tried and sworn well and truly to try said issue of traverse joined between the State of Tennessee and the Defendant, Eddie Cole, a true deliverance make, and a true ver-

dict under according to the law and evi-dence who upon their oaths do say, that the Defendant is guilty in manner and form as charged in the bill of indict-ment and they affix the term of his imprisonment in the Jail and Peni-tentiary hHouse of the State to the period of Five (5) years Whereaupon the Court proceeds to pass sentence which is That the Defendant, Eddie Cole, be taken by the Sheriff of Shelby County at his earliest convenience and ^be^ convey-ed to the Jail and Penitentiary House of this State and delivered to the keeper thereof to be confined therein at hard labor for the period of Five (5) years the time affixed by the jury aforesaid—that the date of his im-prisonment commence from the time of his reception by said keeper—that he be rendered infamous, and incapala-ble of giving evidence in any of the Courts of this State=or of exercising the priveleges of the election Franchise, that he pay the cost of this prosecution and that execution issue

State of Tenn
Shelby County

I, N C Perkins clerk of the Criminal Court of Shelby County, do hereby certify that the above is a true and perfect transcript of the judgement and sen-tence in the case of the State of Tennessee vs. Eddie Cole indictment for Larceny as the same appears of re-cord in my office.
[seal]
In Testimony Whereof, I have unto set my hand and af-fixed the seal of said Court at office in the city of Memphis, this 15th day of April 1875
N C Perkins—Clerk

Be it remembered that on this 29th day of May AD. 1876, before me H L Claiborne a Commissioner for the State of Mississippi, duly commissioned by the Governor thereof, in and for the State of Tennessee, personally came James F. Cummings Deputy warden of the Penitentiary of the State of Tennessee, with whom I am personally acquainted, who made oath in one form of law that the above named Eddie Cole was regularly delivered by the Sheriff of Shelby County Tennessee to the warden of the Penitentiary of the State

of Tennessee at Nashville, ^in obedience to above conviction & sentence^ and that he escaped befhere from before serving out his term of imprison-ment, which was five years, and as affiant is informed and believes is in Jail at Oxford Mississippi, H
J f Cummings Dept warden State Prison
[sea] H. L. CLAIBORNE NASHVILLE TENN STATE OF MISSISSIPPI COMMISIONER OF DEEDS [/seal]
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 29th day of May 1876

H. L. Claiborne
a Commissioner for the State of Mississippi

State of Tennessee
V. S.
Eddie Cole
[Image: plow, haystack, and schooner; inscribed: XVI. AGRICULTURE. COMMERCE.]
To his Excellency, Governor of Mississippi

The undersigned, Governor of the State of Tennessee, would inform your Excellency, that Eddie Cole of this State, charged with ^convicted of^ the crime of Larceny & now an escaped convict from the ^Penitentiary^ as will more fully appear by a copy of an [?] and Affidavit hereunto annexed, which I certify to be authentic, is a fugitive from the Justice of this State, and now supposed to be within the limits of Mississippi

Your Excellency is therefore requested, in conformity to the Constitution and Laws of the United States, to cause the said Eddie Cole to be arrested, if to be found, and delivered to C. E. Butler who is appointed Agent to receive Said Eddie Cole that he may be brought into this State, and be dealt with as to law and justice may appertain
[seal] THE GREAT SEAL OF THE STATE OF TENNESSEE 1796. AGRICULTURE. COMMERCE. [/seal]
